name: Cellular Jail
overview: A national memorial that preserves the story of India's freedom struggle through solitary cells, galleries, and a powerful light and sound show.
whyGo: Trace the journey of India's freedom fighters in an authentic colonial prison
Walk through three-storey wings of solitary cells and central watch tower
Experience the emotional evening light & sound show in Hindi or English
visitTips: Plan 1.5–2 hours in daytime plus a separate visit for the light & sound show
Book show tickets online or via authorized counters in advance during peak season
Carry a bottle of water and wear comfortable footwear for climbing stairs
highlights: Freedom fighter galleries and museum sections
Evening light & sound show in the open courtyard
bestTime: October to May, evenings for the show

name: Corbyn’s Cove Beach
overview: A palm-fringed beach close to the city, popular for relaxed evenings, short walks, and basic water sports.
whyGo: Enjoy an easy-access beach just a short drive from town
Catch breezy sunsets with a city-side vibe
Try simple water sports like jet ski and boat rides when available
visitTips: Best visited during late afternoon and sunset hours
Sea can be rough during monsoon; swimming may be restricted
Street food and small cafés are available along the promenade
highlights: Jet ski and boat rides in season

name: Ross Island (Netaji Subhash Chandra Bose Island)
overview: The former British administrative headquarters now covered in tree roots, ruins, and sea views, a short boat ride from Port Blair.
whyGo: Explore overgrown colonial ruins wrapped in banyan roots
Enjoy panoramic harbour views and sea breeze
Meet friendly deer and peacocks roaming freely on the island
visitTips: Carry water and sun protection; shade is patchy on sunny days
Ferry timings are fixed; plan to return by the last boat
Wear sturdy footwear for walking on uneven paths and steps
highlights: Ruins of church, bakery, and officers’ quarters
Viewpoints facing Port Blair and open sea
bestTime: October to March, mornings or late afternoons

name: North Bay Island (Coral Island)
overview: A small offshore island famous for shallow coral reefs, glass-bottom rides, snorkeling, and sea walking.
whyGo: Try first-time snorkeling in relatively shallow waters
Experience glass-bottom boat rides to view corals and fish
Opt for sea-walk helmet experiences when operational
visitTips: Book activities in advance during high season to avoid waiting
Follow safety briefing carefully before any underwater activity
Non-swimmers can enjoy glass-bottom rides without getting wet
highlights: View of lighthouse featured on Indian currency note
bestTime: November to April, mornings for calmer seas

name: Chidiya Tapu (Sunset Point)
overview: A quiet coastal stretch and mangrove-fringed area known for sunset views, birdlife, and a short trek to a viewpoint.
whyGo: Watch colourful sunsets over forested hills and sea
Stroll along mangrove-lined shores and rocky beaches
Optionally hike to Chidiya Tapu viewpoint for aerial vistas
visitTips: Start early if attempting the viewpoint hike; carry water
Avoid going too close to rocky edges during high tide
Return towards town soon after sunset as the road gets dark
highlights: Short trek to elevated viewpoint (for fit travellers)

name: Mount Harriet National Park
overview: A hilly national park with dense forests, cool breeze, and viewpoints looking back towards Port Blair and surrounding islands.
whyGo: Escape city heat into cooler forested hills
Enjoy viewpoints that feature on the old Rs. 20 note scenery
Spot butterflies and listen to forest sounds on short walks
visitTips: Carry packed snacks and water; food options are limited
Leech protection is useful in monsoon months
Respect park timings and avoid littering in the forest
highlights: Short forest trails and picnic spots
bestTime: November to March, mornings and late afternoons

name: Anthropological Museum
overview: A compact museum offering insights into the indigenous tribes, history, and anthropology of the Andaman & Nicobar Islands.
whyGo: Learn about the native communities of the islands
See traditional tools, models, and photographs
Understand the social and cultural history beyond beaches
visitTips: Allocate 45–60 minutes for a relaxed walkthrough
Photography may be restricted in some sections
Combine with visits to Samudrika and Cellular Jail for a museum circuit

name: Samudrika Naval Marine Museum
overview: A well-organised museum by the Indian Navy showcasing Andaman’s marine life, geography, tribal history, and environment.
whyGo: Get a compact introduction to Andaman’s geography and reefs
View preserved marine specimens and shells
Good first-day stop to understand the overall archipelago
visitTips: Ideal to visit on arrival day before island-hopping
Check current opening hours and weekly holidays
Great for travellers who enjoy structured exhibits

name: Aberdeen Jetty & Marina Park
overview: A waterfront strip from where many day boats depart, combined with a seaside promenade and park area for short walks.
whyGo: Catch ferries and boats to nearby islands like Ross and North Bay
Take an evening stroll along the waterfront promenade
Enjoy quick snacks and casual views of the harbour
visitTips: Arrive at least 30–45 minutes before scheduled boat departure
Keep tickets and ID proofs handy for checks
Be careful with luggage and electronics near the waterline
bestTime: Year-round, mornings for departures and evenings for walks

name: Jogger’s Park Viewpoint
overview: A small hilltop park overlooking the runway and city, popular for quiet evening walks and panoramic views.
whyGo: Watch flights land and take off from an elevated viewpoint
Enjoy breezy, relatively peaceful surroundings in the city
Capture night-time views of Port Blair lights
visitTips: Best visited around sunset and early night
Carry a light jacket if you feel cold easily
Combine with dinner in nearby local restaurants

name: Radhanagar Beach (Beach No. 7)
overview: A wide arc of soft white sand backed by forest, often rated among Asia’s best beaches, ideal for leisurely swims and sunsets.
whyGo: Relax on a postcard-perfect white-sand beach
Swim in clear blue waters with gentle waves (in season)
Watch dramatic sunsets with silhouettes of trees and hills
visitTips: Swimming is typically allowed in the demarcated zones; follow lifeguard flags
Avoid swimming after sunset and during rough sea warnings
Minimal shops on the beach—carry water and essentials
highlights: Forest line right behind the sand
bestTime: November to April, late afternoon till sunset

name: Kalapathar Beach
overview: A quieter stretch of coastline lined with black rocks and casuarina trees, known for calm walks and photo spots.
whyGo: Escape to a less crowded scenic beach corner
Click photos with dark rocks and light sand contrast
Enjoy peaceful mornings away from central Havelock
visitTips: Parts of the beach can be rocky; watch your step near the water
Best enjoyed as a short stop rather than a full-day stay
Carry water; only small stalls may be open
bestTime: November to April, mornings and early evenings

name: Elephant Beach (via Boat)
overview: A popular day-excursion beach accessible by boat, offering vibrant reefs near shore and multiple water activities.
whyGo: Snorkel or take glass-bottom rides over colourful reefs
Try popular water sports like sea walk and jet ski in one zone
Ideal first spot for non-swimmers to experience coral life
visitTips: Book boat and activities in advance during busy months
Follow instructions strictly for life jacket and underwater safety
Limited shade and basic stalls; carry essentials in a waterproof bag
highlights: Short boat ride from Havelock jetty
Cluster of activity operators on one beach
Shallow reef patches visible close to shore
bestTime: November to April, mornings when waters are calmer

name: Govind Nagar Beach (Havelock Main Beach)
overview: The main stretch of shoreline where many dive centres and beachside stays are located, offering convenient access to the sea.
whyGo: Stay at beach-facing properties with easy sea access
Join introductory scuba dives with nearby operators
Walk along shallow lagoons at low tide
visitTips: Tide conditions change the feel of the beach through the day
Check with your dive centre about start points and timings
Respect coral patches; avoid stepping on live reef areas
durationSuggested: Half day or more if staying nearby

name: Vijay Nagar Beach (Beach No. 5)
overview: A tranquil beachfront area with lagoon-like waters at certain tides, ideal for slow walks and relaxed stays.
whyGo: Enjoy quieter beachfront resorts and homestays
Walk on long sandbars at low tide
Good base for couples or slow travellers
visitTips: Tidal charts influence swimming and walking options
Some areas may have seagrass; water shoes can help
Best combined with staying in nearby properties
highlights: Good for stargazing on clear nights
durationSuggested: Half day or overnight stay base

name: Dive Sites off Havelock (Generic Entry)
overview: Multiple boat-access and shore-access dive sites around Havelock, managed by certified dive operators.
whyGo: Experience Andaman’s most popular recreational scuba hub
See reefs, schooling fish, and occasional turtles or rays
Take beginner-friendly Discover Scuba sessions or full courses
visitTips: Always dive with a licensed, well-reviewed operator
Avoid flying for at least 18–24 hours after your last dive
Declare any medical conditions honestly in dive forms
highlights: Variety of dive sites with different depths
Underwater photography options with some operators
bestTime: December to April for best visibility

name: Bharatpur Beach
overview: The activity hub of Neil Island with shallow turquoise waters, boat rides, and snorkelling options close to the jetty.
whyGo: Ideal for glass-bottom boat rides and casual snorkelling
Shallow lagoon suitable for families in suitable conditions
Colourful beach shacks and stalls along the shore
visitTips: Good spot for a relaxed half-day on arrival or departure day
Tides affect water depth; check with locals for best slots
Keep an eye on belongings while entering the water
highlights: Activity and snack zone of Neil

name: Laxmanpur Beach I & II
overview: Twin stretches famous for sunset views, natural rock formations, and tide pools with marine life.
whyGo: Watch sunset with wide open horizon views
Explore the natural rock bridge near low tide
Look for small fish and creatures in tide pools
visitTips: Check low-tide timings if you want to see the rock bridge properly
Rocks can be slippery; wear footwear with good grip
Arrive 60–90 minutes before sunset for best light and exploration time

name: Sitapur Beach (Sunrise Point)
overview: An east-facing beach with rocky edges and open sea views, known as a peaceful sunrise point.
whyGo: Catch sunrise over the Bay of Bengal
Experience a quiet, less commercialised side of Neil
Listen to strong waves crashing on rock formations
visitTips: Start early; it’s darker and quieter before dawn
Sea here is usually not suitable for casual swimming
Carry a torch or phone light for the approach path in early hours

name: Limestone Caves (Baratang)
overview: An adventurous day trip involving road convoy, boat through mangroves, and a walk to see limestone cave formations.
whyGo: Experience a mixed journey of road, creek boat, and forest walk
See stalactite and stalagmite formations inside the caves
Pass through mangrove-lined waterways on the way
visitTips: Day trip requires early start from Port Blair with permits
Walking path can be humid; carry water and a cap
Respect forest and tribal buffer norms on the route

name: Mud Volcano (Baratang)
overview: A small cluster of mud volcano vents, an unusual geological feature reached by a short walk from the road.
whyGo: See slowly bubbling mud vents in a natural depression
Tick off a rare geological sight few have seen
Combine with limestone caves on the same day trip
visitTips: Expect a simple, low-key sight rather than a dramatic geyser
Wear sturdy footwear for the slightly uneven trail
Best visited in dry season when path is less slippery

name: Amkunj Beach (Eco Park)
overview: A rocky shoreline turned into an eco-park with wooden benches and sea-facing sit-outs along the Andaman Trunk Road.
whyGo: Break the long road journey with a scenic sea stop
Sit on wooden platforms facing waves and breeze
Good leg-stretch point between Port Blair and North Andaman
visitTips: Swimming is generally not recommended due to rocks
Carry snacks and water; facilities are basic
Nice photo and rest stop for road-trippers

name: Dhanninalah Mangrove Walkway
overview: A long wooden boardwalk through mangroves leading to a quiet beach, showcasing the area’s ecosystem.
whyGo: Walk over elevated wooden paths within mangroves
Observe crabs, birds, and inter-tidal life
End at a silent beach away from main road noise
visitTips: Boardwalk can be hot under direct sun; carry a cap
Ideal for nature lovers and photographers
Combine with Amkunj and nearby eco spots
bestTime: November to March, mornings or late afternoons

name: Ross & Smith Twin Islands
overview: Two small islands connected by a sandbar, surrounded by clear water, accessed by a permitted boat ride from Diglipur.
whyGo: Walk on a natural sandbar joining two islands
Swim in turquoise shallows on a good-weather day
Enjoy a picnic-style outing in a remote northern setting
visitTips: Permits and fixed boat timings apply; plan through local agents
Respect no-plastic norms and carry back all waste
Tides can submerge parts of the sandbar; check tide timings

name: Saddle Peak National Park (Viewpoint Trek)
overview: A demanding trek to the highest peak of the Andaman Islands, rewarding hikers with dense forest and aerial sea views.
whyGo: Challenge yourself with one of the tougher treks in Andaman
Walk through thick tropical forest with bird calls
Get panoramic views of coastline and islands from the top
visitTips: Trek requires good fitness; start very early in the morning
Carry sufficient water, snacks, and rain protection
Permits and local guidance are recommended; check latest rules
bestTime: December to February, clear and cooler days
durationSuggested: Full day for ascent and descent

name: Kalipur Beach & Turtle Nesting Zone
overview: A pebbly beach known seasonally for turtle nesting, located in a quieter northern corner of the islands.
whyGo: Witness turtle nesting and release programs in season (with permissions)
Experience a raw, non-commercial beach setting
Stay in simple local accommodations nearby
visitTips: Turtle sightings are seasonal and not guaranteed
Access to nesting areas is regulated; always follow forest department guidelines
Beach is not ideal for typical swimming due to pebbles and currents
bestTime: December to March for potential turtle season

name: Butler Bay Beach
overview: A long, curved bay with strong waves, coconut groves, and a more offbeat surf-vibe ambience.
whyGo: Experience one of the more remote and wild-feeling beaches
Popular with experienced surfers in specific seasons
Good for long, uncrowded walks along the shoreline
visitTips: Sea conditions can be strong; casual swimming is often not advised
Limited tourism infrastructure; suited for basic-travel style
Check current transport and stay options before planning
bestTime: December to March, outside heavy monsoon
durationSuggested: Half day or more if staying nearby

name: White Surf & Whisper Wave Waterfalls (Generic Entry)
overview: Forest-fringed waterfalls in the interior of Little Andaman, reached by short treks or bike rides depending on conditions.
whyGo: Combine beach time with freshwater dips in jungle settings
Enjoy motorbike rides or jeep journeys to the trailheads
See a lesser-visited side of the islands away from the main circuit
visitTips: Waterfall flow is seasonal; check local advice before heading
Trails may be slippery during or after rains
Carry adequate water, insect repellent, and waterproof bags
bestTime: Post-monsoon to early winter, when flow is moderate and access is safe

name: Long Island Village & Lalaji Bay (Generic Entry)
overview: A quieter island with a small settlement, forest trails and boat ride options towards serene Lalaji Bay Beach.
whyGo: Step into a slower, community-based island atmosphere
Walk or boat through creeks and forested paths
Spend time on a tranquil, less-frequented bay
visitTips: Access usually requires coordination with ferries and local boats
Accommodation and amenities are limited; plan in advance
Suited for slow travellers who enjoy simple stays and walks
highlights: Creeks and forest sections en route
